    Mr Speaker: Mr Prime Minister, Leader of the House, Members of the Government and Members of the, Opposition ---

    I am honoured to be elected Speaker of this House. I would, however, be more comfortable in the seat below reserved for the Member for Tanglin.

    I am consoled by the assurance that I will be required to shoulder the responsibility for only a short period. Whilst I am here, I will endeavour to discharge my duties to the best of my ability with patience and impartiality and, I hope, to the satisfaction of both sides of the House.

Column: 6



    I would ask all the Members to assist me to conduct these proceedings in accordance with the rules of procedure and the Standing Orders of this House and, above all, with decorum.

    Dr Toh Chin Chye: Mr Speaker, it is the practice of parliamentary legislatures modelled after Westminster to elect a Speaker from among Members of the House who have, in turn, been elected by the people. However, it has been provided in the Constitution of the State of Singapore that our Legislature can elect as Speaker either a Member of this House itself, or a person from outside the House. Your election, Mr Speaker, is in keeping with our constitutional procedure and parliamentary practice prevailing in many countries. You yourself, Mr Speaker, have indicated that you will occupy the Chair for only a temporary period. It is our intention at a future date to elect a Puisne Judge to the Chair. The consent of the Central Government, who is now responsible for the judiciary, must of course be sought.

    Mr Speaker, it has been an honour to have proposed you as Speaker of the Legislative Assembly. I have no doubt that the experience you have acquired as a respected member of the Bar will stand you in good stead in your present office. You have had a distinguished academic record in your student days and, if I can recollect accurately, you were, besides being a scholar, a skilled sportsman. I am told cricket was your favourite game - a very fair game indeed compared to the hurly burly of soccer and rugby football, in which sometimes the referee becomes the object of uncomplimentary remarks and the target of missiles from the players and the gallery. You yourself, Mr Speaker, must have umpired many a cricket game in your time, and just as you have fairly acted as umpire on the cricket pitch, we have no doubt that you will also be an able umpire in this House, and that you will observe that the rules of the game are played as indicated in the Standing Orders.

    Mr Ong Eng Guan (Hong Lim): Mr Speaker, Sir, as one who has known you

Column: 7

for many years, I have no doubt, as you have said just now, that you will chair the sittings of this Assembly, during the time when you are the Speaker or later on when you are the Deputy Speaker, with fairness, patience and impartiality that will transcend party politics despite the fact that you are a Member of the Government Party, as the previous Deputy Speaker of this House who was also a Member of the Government had done so.

    Of course, we in the Opposition do mourn the loss of Mr George Oehlers - the great Speaker who has established parliamentary democracy in this State - and we do not hesitate to say that we would like to see him here with us again, but that is something about which we in the Opposition cannot do very much. But anyway, Mr Speaker, Sir, with for many years, we have no doubt of your impartiality and we have every confidence that you will be able to carry out the traditions which have been laid in this Assembly by the previous Speaker.

YANG DI-PERTUAN NEGARA'S SPEECH AT CEREMONIAL
OPENING OF ASSEMBLY
(Statement by the Prime Minister)


    The Prime Minister (Mr Lee Kuan Yew): Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to explain briefly why it has not been possible to have the ceremonial opening of the Assembly with a speech from His Excellency the Yang di-Pertuan Negara at the first meeting following upon the general elections. On the 23rd July this year in the last Assembly, all the Opposition Parties - the Barisan Sosialis, the Alliance, and the United People's Party - and two Independents blocked a Bill for general election of 15 Members to the Central Parliament.

    Members are aware that the Speaker of Parliament has asked us for the names of the 15 representatives from Singapore. These Members will take their places as Members of the House of Representatives on 2nd November, in just over a week's time. It is not possible before the 2nd of November to have a speech by His Excellency the Yang di-Pertuan Negara, thereafter seven clear days' adjournment, followed by a debate on the motion of thanks to the Yang di-Pertuan Negara, and then a Bill for the election of 15 seats - all this to be completed before 2nd November. We have, therefore, had to make an adjustment and have, in today's business session, the swearing in of new Members and the passage of this Bill for 15 Members to the Central Parliament.

    After we have ascertained when the business sittings of Parliament in Kuala Lumpur will be in November and December, the date for the ceremonial opening of this Assembly will be fixed when His Excellency the Yang di-Pertuan Negara will give his speech setting out the programme and policy of the Government for the next year.

    Mr Ong Eng Guan: Mr Speaker, the reasons given by the Prime Minister

Column: 11

for today's proceedings do not convince us in the Opposition. This Government was elected on the 21st of September, and if they had wanted they could have had the ceremonial opening sometime towards the end of September.

    Mr Speaker: A debate on a ministerial statement is not regular. Members, however, can ask questions arising from the contents of the statement provided that these questions are phrased in the form of questions and are relevant to the subject matter of the statement. Would the Member for Hong Lim please phrase his question?

    Mr Ong Eng Guan: Mr Speaker, I would like to ask the Prime Minister whether it was possible to have a Government formed by the 23rd or 25th of September and the Yang di-Pertuan Negara's speech made towards the end of September and the beginning of October. If that could have been done, we could have this Bill to send 15 representatives to Parliament even earlier than today, which is the 22nd of October.

    The Prime Minister: Mr Speaker, Sir, I would not wish to quarrel with what the Member for Hong Lim were to do if he were the Government and he were the Prime Minister. That is the prerogative which I would accord him if he were in fact the leader of the majority Party. However, he should accord us at least the courtesy of allowing us to conduct the affairs of Singapore in a manner which befits the solemnity of the business of State which we have to dispose of. Ministers are not appointed at random. Matters of State are not disposed of in order to suit the newspapers or, for that matter, in order to suit the opening of the Federal Parliament. There are certain matters which have to be considered in their respective priorities, and we consider that the first policy statement of this Government which shall he contained in the Yang di-Pertuan Negara's speech is one which deserves careful consideration before its delivery.

SINGAPORE (ELECTION TO THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES) BILL
First Reading


    The Prime Minister: Mr Speaker, Sir, I lay upon the table a Certificate of Urgency signed by the Yang di-Pertuan Negara in respect of the Singapore (Election to the House of Representatives) Bill.

    Certificate of Urgency handed in.

    Mr Speaker: The Certificate is in order. Please proceed.

    The Prime Minister: Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to introduce a Bill intituled "An Ordinance to provide for the first election of Members of the House of Representatives of the Federation from Singapore."

    Printed copies of the Bill have already been handed to the Clerk earlier this morning.

    Bill read the First time.
Second Reading


    Mr Speaker: Second Reading, what day?

    The Prime Minister: Now, Sir, If the Clerk will distribute copies of the Bill to hon. Members.

    Printed copies of the Bill distributed to hon. Members.

    Mr Speaker: Please proceed.

    The Prime Minister: Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    Sir, Members will notice that the Bill provides for the election of 15 Members to the Central Parliament in accordance with section 95 of the Malaysia Act. For the enlightenment of Members who were not present at the last Assembly when this Act was adopted, if I may read section 95 (1) of the Act. It says:

    `Subject to subsection (2), Part VIII of the Constitution shall not have effect for the purpose of elections of members of the House

Column: 13

of Representatives from Singapore until the second general election to that House held after Malaysia Day, and so long as this subsection applies to those elections those members shall, subject to subsection (2), be elected as may be provided by any law passed by the Legislature of Singapore with the concurrence of the Yang di-Pertuan Agong (including any law so passed before Malaysia Day), and the period for which they are elected should be the period until the second dissolution of Parliament after Malaysia Day.'

Sir, Members on the Opposition side, even those who were not Members of this Chamber in the last session, will know that the Government introduced a Bill for the election of 15 Members direct from 15 constituencies in Singapore, such constituencies to be formed by grouping in threes and fours the existing 51 constituencies to form 15. My colleague, the then Minister for Home Affairs, invited all leaders of the Opposition Parties to put up their proposals as to how these constituencies were to be formed. For diverse reasons, each Party having a separate reason, the Opposition teamed up to defeat or, if I may be more accurate, to prevent the passage of the Bill, with the votes tying on the Second Reading.

    Sir, on the eve of nomination on the 11th of September, I made a broadcast in which I stated as a main plank of the Government's platform, the P.A.P. platform, that the election was to be one for 51 seats and also for 15 seats, the 15 to be elected from the 51. I do not recall, Mr Speaker, Sir, having read any contrary platform being put forward by any Opposition Party. I did, however, subsequently read, when the election results had been declared for the 51 seats, that the leader of the Barisan Sosialis, who is no longer in this Chamber, would now prefer to go back to 15 seats in a direct election.

    Sir, I do not wish to labour this point. But it does not require much ingenuity, now that we know the results of the elections on a party basis, constituency by constituency, to so re-arrange the 51 constituencies in such a way as to give a parity of total votes in 15 in which the Barisan would probably not win even a single seat. But that would be an exercise in ingenuity which would not necessarily be in the interest of the

Column: 14

country. We could even, by this collegiate election which we have done and which we made an issue of at the elections, like the Borneo territories, take all the 15 seats to ourselves. But again that would not be in the interest of the country. It is useful to Malaysia and its 10 million inhabitants to be constantly reminded of the presence of people who, whatever they now piously say about defending the sovereignty of Malaysia, have as their primary object the destruction of the nation we have founded. I would not wish to arrogate to Members of this Chamber generally the right to nominate and vote for three Members of the Barisan Sosialis, because that is a matter for them to decide. Whether they would wish to send three of their most affable and amiable colleagues in order to smooth the way with the other 159 Members in Parliament, or whether they would choose to send their three fiercest ones is a matter I leave completely in their hands.

    But I would say to them that they should bear this in mind - that all the great issues which have agitated this Chamber over the last nine years since 1955 - anti-colonialism, abolition of the Preservation of Public Security Ordinance, denunciation and condemnation of arrests and detention without trial, brutality of Fascist police force - all these burning issues of the moment unfortunately are no longer within the preserve of the jurisdiction of this Chamber. Mr Speaker, we meet now, as I hope from time to time we will, for the more constructive if less exciting purpose of getting on with the job of building an industrial base in Singapore, rebuilding the old City and producing the things for which the people have elected us. There will not be the great issues of foreign policy, defence, security, confrontation, all the things that filled this Chamber with so many long hours of debate. I do not know whether the Central Parliament will concede to what we have followed in this Chamber, allowing them on one occasion, if I remember correctly, no less than eight continuous hours of filibustering. I would say it is for them to decide how they would wish to take

Column: 15

advantage of the three seats that they will have out of the 159 seats in the Central Parliament. No doubt it is their desire and their express intention to join up with other so-called Socialist forces in the Central Parliament. We look forward to meeting them there for the exciting debates on security, defence and foreign affairs and all the other great things in life which agitate the Communists and the pro-Communists.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move.

11.35 a.m.

    Mr Chia Thye Poh (Jurong)(In Mandarin): The Member for Tanjong Pagar has introduced this Bill known as the Singapore (Election to the House of Representatives) Bill. The basic spirit and principles of this Bill, he says, are founded on the results of the State election according to the proportion of representation of the Party in power and the Opposition to elect 15 Members to the Central Parliament. We must point out that the P.A.P. conducted a very unfair and undemocratic general election, and after this unfair and undemocratic election, the P.A.P. is tabling another unreasonable Bill in this House. We must point out, in the first place, that the State election was meant for the election of State Assemblymen. Before the election and even in the course of the election in all the Government's statements and circulars and in the platforms of the various political Parties, there was no disclosure of the intention to elect Members from the State Assembly ---

    The Prime Minister: May I on a point of information, Sir?

    Mr Speaker: Yes.

    The Prime Minister: The Member who was speaking had not the advantage of being in the last Chamber. If I may more slowly read this section of the Malaysia Act, a great deal of the written material which he has, I am quite sure with great diligence, compiled may

Column: 16

appear to him to he completely irrelevant. Section 95 of the Malaysia Act, which is adopted in this House, provides that legislation shall be introduced either before or after Malaysia Day in this Legislative Assembly for the election of 15 Members. We introduced direct elections for 15 Members. The Bill was blocked. We then had general elections of 51 seats, and on the eve of nomination we, the Government Party, made it an issue that if we were returned, a Bill would be introduced in order to select 15 representatives from Members of this House. The normal principle underlining such an issue is quite simple. A matter has been made the main plank in an election issue. The votes have been given, the matter is resolved. I am quite happy to hear the Member out and answer him. But he should bear in mind that these points have already been taken up in this Chamber and he has to pick up the argument from the fact that his own Party had blocked the election of 15 seats, brought about the general elections in which we said that we had no intention of repeating another general election for 15 seats at the expense of three-quarters of a million dollars.

    Mr Speaker: Will the Member for Jurong please proceed?

    Mr Chia Thye Poh(In Mandarin): The Member for Tanjong Pagar has just now said that we prevented the passage of the Bill to elect 15 representatives to the Central Parliament. That is why this matter was made an election issue in the State general election. That is why it is the intention of the Government to elect from among the Members in this House 15 persons to the Central Parliament. I must point out that in the last Assembly, our Party opposed the Bill known as the Singapore (Elections to the Federal House of Representatives) Bill. That was a matter of chronological order which has nothing to do with the principles of this Bill. Our opposition then was one matter and this Bill now is another matter. We must point out that the State general election was intended for the people to elect State Assemblymen. In the minds of the

Column: 17

people, after the general election, there would be another election for the election of representatives to the Central Parliament. That was the impression the people got. It was very simple. In the minds of the people, in the general election they only had to elect representatives to this House and not representatives to the Central Parliament as well. So, if one is to base the representation on the results of the State general election and elect 15 Members to the Central Parliament, then that will not be a true election made by the people, because some people who have elected Members to this House may not agree to the same representatives to the Central Parliament. Then some people who have not been elected to this House might be agreed to as being suitable representatives to the Central Parliament. So shortly before the general election, the P.A.P. declared that the State general election would also be an election for representatives to the Central Parliament. But there was no mention of the nomination of representatives by the Assembly in the State to the Central Parliament ---

    The Prime Minister: Sir, if the Member will allow me, I will produce a copy of my broadcast which will set out the issues that I placed on the 11th of September ---

    Mr Speaker: On a point of information. If the Member for Jurong wishes to give way to the Prime Minister, he may; otherwise, please proceed.

    Mr Chia Thye Poh(In Mandarin): But after the undemocratic and unfair State general election, the P.A.P. saw that it was able to obtain a majority vote in the State general election. So according to the proportion represented by both sides, the Party in power is getting an advantage.
